choices.B: The router is placed in bridge mode, the modem is placed behind the router, and the web server is placed behind the modem.
choices.A: The modem is placed in bridge mode, the router is placed behind the modem, and the web server is placed behind the router.
choices.C: The web server is placed in bridge mode, the router is placed behind the web server, and the modem is placed behind the router.
choices.D: The switch is placed in bridge mode, the modem is placed behind the router, and the router is placed behind the modem.

questions.question_text: A technician is replacing a failed SOHO router for a customer who has an existing switch, cable modem, and static IP address. The user has a web server that faces the Internet so users can visit and leave comments. Which of the following BEST describes the correct configuration for this customer's requirements?

comments.content: I seriously believe this exam was made by goofy pot heads that smoke all day on a couch and just write down exam questions as they watch netflix shows

discussion.content: wtf is this question man

choices.C: Nightly backups are consuming excessive bandwidth.
choices.B: A light source is creating EMI interference, affecting the UTP cabling.
choices.A: The router has a time-based ACL, applied for the network segment.
choices.D: The user has violated the AUP, and Internet access has been restricted.

questions.question_text: A network technician is attempting to troubleshoot a connectivity issue. The issue is only reported during the evening hours, and only a single workstation loses connectivity. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause of the issue?

comments.content: yup, I see what you're saying. A worker violates AUP but reports loss of connectivity to the IT dept! Gotta love CompTIA!
The light source might only affect the user's computer though, depending on where it is.
The question is: "a connectivity issue." Answer D only refers to internet access and not the LAN.
Connectivity issue can refer to LAN

discussion.content: With A B & C the whole network will be affected. Even though D seems wrong, it’s the only situation where only one system is affected. Annoying but correct.

The question implies this happens every evening(otherwise a key piece of info, that it only happens SOME evenings, goes unmentioned). So the person is breaching the AUP every single day. Is that a reasonable thing to expect us to assume? Especially with the mention of this only happening in the evenings, when lighting would reasonably kick in.
i hope i will not get this in the exam
Honestly think they're trolling with us. Firmly believe answer is B

The AUP thing. I’d never guessed it. I thought probably the lights turning on caused EMI on that particular network cable. - - Besides, what company allows an employee to violate the AUP every single day? You’d think they’d have a counseling session after a while.

A time-based ACL can block certain IP addresses. EMI can affect the wireless network even wired network if cables are very close to each other but C and D don't make any sense.
https://networklessons.com/cisco/ccie-routing-switching-written/cisco-ios-time-based-access-list
https://www.astrodynetdi.com/blog/emi-filter-basics
based on the fact that the question specified that "The question implies this happens every evening", I think the most reasonable answer is A
Every day at a certain time some one searches inappropriate things. Noted

"The issue is only reported during the evening hours", meaning the issue has happened numerous times. I would think the tech will be aware of the violation, so trouble shooting would not be necessary. This question of poorly structured. But, by process of elimination D has to be the answer. Answers A B and C will not effect a single computer.

It appears to me that correct answer is D. The user has violated the AUP, and Internet access has been restricted. It seems that time logon restrictions are set for this single workstation based on AUP.

As far as I'm concerned this question is trash and there isn't a correct answer here. My biggest problem is that we're to infer that this employee violates the AUP every day and just gets their workstation throttled as a consequence? Yeah, no. They'd be fired.

comments.content: Yes...

discussion.content: I'm going with B here. Why would a user's internet only be restricted at night? Is he watching porn at work or what?
The user violated the policy and restricted to use an access during at night. And note there was only one workstation affected of the entire network.

comments.content: Yeah, it's one of those questions where you have to think about it a bit. Other questions, you have to think less. It's a weird dichotomy
WRONG WRONG WRONG. An EMI interference on a specific UTP cabling for a single workstation can affect that workstation alone.

discussion.content: A,B & C will affect not only a "SINGLE" workstation but others as well so yeah D is right. Read the question properly guys. It's free and it's good brain exercise.

I think the correct answer should be "B. A light source is creating EMI interference, affecting the UTP cabling." If the cabling was optical fiber, then I would agree with the given answer. However, the issue is only reported during evening hours (likely due to the overhead lighting turning on when it gets dark) and only a single workstation loses connectivity (likely due to the workstation location and overhead lighting location) -- additionally, UTP cables are susceptible to electromagnetic interference.

comments.content: Further, UTP cabling is more commonly used inside an office building than optical fiber, due to cost. As such, I think option B is the MOST likely cause of the issue.

discussion.content: Theres no such thing as a honeyspot, only honeypot or honeynet.

comments.content: Probably it’s a typo.

discussion.content: "safe environment and determine the method of attack" keywords: safe environment" & "determine the method of attack" while "determine the method of attack" would obviously be related to a Honeypot or Honeynet, "safe environment" describes a Honeynet in someway, cause Honeynets are intended to be put in an area where security are not present so administrators can study attack patterns and behaviour. Though it seems "unsafe" but in a defensive perspective, since Honeynets are place outside the internal network then even if attackers would bombard the Honeynets the internal network won't be affected.
Is creating a honeypot really a safe environment though?

comments.content: What happens in honeypot, stays in honeypot!

In this case, safe environment means a place where nothing can affect your network. What happens in a honeypot, presumably stays in there. AND it answers admin's requirement that they can monitor what is going on.

questions.question_text: A network administrator is redesigning network security after an attack. During the attack, an attacker used open cubicle locations to attach devices to the network. The administrator wants to be able to monitor future attacks in a safe environment and determine the method of attack. Which of the following should the administrator do to BEST meet this requirement?

choices.A: Create a VLAN for the unused ports and create a honeyspot on the VLAN.
choices.C: Create a DMZ for public servers and secure a segment for the internal network.
choices.B: Install a BPDU guard on switchports and enable STP.
choices.D: Install antivirus software and set an ACL on the servers.

questions.question_text: A company has just refreshed the hardware in its datacenter with new 10G Ethernet switches. A technician wishes to set up a new storage area network but must use existing infrastructure. Which of the following storage standards should the technician use?

discussion.content: NAS is only storage standards out of answers....

comments.content: No its not.
but he does have a point....NAS is the only storage option here. The others are protocols for SAN

discussion.content:
Answer is A. iSCSI

"When it comes to infrastructure to support a SAN, there are three main choices: Fibre Channel, iSCSI, InfiniBand."
-Network+ Certification Exam N10-007, Mike Meyers, Page 565

The question/scenario states the technician wants to set up a storage area network (SAN), therefore I think it would have to be one of the three standards listed above.

-NAS is a totally separate device and we are not sure whether it exists in the infrastructure, but we are definitely not given anything to make us think it does exist in the infrastructure already. It is also not a standard.
-Fibre Channel requires "its own cables, protocols, and switches, all increasing the cost associated with its use (p. 565)." This would require equipment in addition to the existing infrastructure so this can't be the answer.
-InfiniBand "has unique NICs and cabling (p.566)" which would also require equipment in addition to the existing infrastructure so this can't be the answer.
-"iSCSI is built on top of TCP/IP (p.565)" which would require NO additional equipment and uses the existing infrastructure.
key word in question is "Ethernet". With a NAS you typically use Ethernet to access storage. With a SAN you use fibre channel SCSI to access the data. Answer is NAS.

iSCSI is traditionally less expensive than Fibre Channel to implement
Can be done with only software
iSCSI can run over preexisting copper infrastructure and use preexisting switches and routers
iSCSI does not require specially trained network administrators to manage the network

I said iSCSI too but looking it up i see references to there being two "standard" types of network storage, called Network Attached Storage (NAS) and Storage Area Network (SAN). 
Maybe they view them as standards and the other options as protocols. 
When you think of it, is SAN a protocol? If not then neither is NAS. 
Anyway stupid question, but thats what were up against.
https://www.dataplugs.com/en/network-storage-the-differences-between-nas-and-san/
They ask for a SAN and get a NAS? What?
The question should be "set up a new Network-attached storage" In this case C would be the correct answer.
And this why I hate CompTIA. If a bunch of us petition and complain about questions lke these, I bet they would stop their nonsense!

iSCSI is a storage area networking protocol that defines how data is transferred between host systems and storage devices. It enables block-level SCSI data transport between the iSCSI initiator and the storage target over TCP/IP networks. iSCSI storage is also known as iSCSI SAN storage, which is a cost-effective alternative to traditional Fibre Channel (FC) SAN. Unlike FC SAN which requires dedicated hardware (FC HBA, FC switch, etc.), iSCSI SAN storage can be built on existing network infrastructure (A) is the correct anser

check this out from Dion training; iSCSI (IP Small Computer System Interface)
o Lower cost, built using Ethernet switches (<10 Gbps)
o Relies on configuration allowing jumbo frames over the
network
NAS is correct answer as question says use current infrastructure

comments.content: NAS is not current infrastructure. You would need to buy a whole NAS unit to implement it. The answer is iSCSI.

discussion.content: A technician wishes to use the new storage which is the iSCSI. iSCSI performance level is better than NAS but the technician wants to use the existing infrastructure so the answer is NAS.
iSCSI, if you do a Google search, is interchangeably called a protocol AND a standard all over the place. The wiki article alone calls it BOTH. Which is actually true?

comments.content: Nowhere can I find NAS referred to as a standard..

discussion.content:
"use existing infrastructure" I assume it means not needing another server.
NAS; Network is attached to storage, so no new independent server?

comments.content: the question refers to 'storage standards' not packets carriers
No, ISCSI uses preexisting infrastructure to set up a "storage area network" NAS is not a SAN and is only 1 device. I am 100% sure it's ISCSI.

"A technician wishes to set up a new storage area network but must use existing infrastructure. Which of the following storage standards should the technician use?"
Pretty contradictory I should say. Following what technician wants- it is SAN, as of question formulated and options given- NAS is the only storage standart among other answers. Shitty formulation, contradictory in itself.
I agree that it should be iSCSI. The question states the tech wants to use the "existing" network "before" he sets up a NAS. It's obvious the NAS doesn't exist yet. So how could the answer be NAS.

A NAS device is NOT A STORAGE AREA NETWORK. 

iSCSI is used to create SANs.
It says the technician "wishes" to set up a new storage area network but "must" use existing infrastructure. So the NAS does already exist.

discussion.content: I am fairly certain the answer is actually iSCSI. iSCI carries SCSI commands over IP using standard Ethernet switches and is optimized for IP networks.
This question is bullshit for this exam.
The question is ambiguous. It doesn't say what kind of GBIC or SFP they are using. There are all sorts of SFP and GBIC ( single fiber, WDM , duplex etc.....)

comments.content: The TLDR definition of transpose means to flip. In this case change the pairs orientation going into the adapter.

discussion.content: Anyone knows how it is C?

questions.question_text: A network technician needs to install a new access switch. After installing the new switch, the technician begins to move connections from the old switch to the new switch. The old switch used a GBIC with SC connectors, and the new switch uses an SFP with LC connectors. After connecting the SC connector to the SC- to-LC adapter and plugging it into the switch, the link does not come up as expected. Which of the following should a network technician perform NEXT?

choices.B: Fall back to the old switch.
choices.A: Replace SFP with a new one.
